item.title: PhD defence
item.description: I defended my PhD titled “Design and Security Analysis of Lattice-based Post-Quantum Encryption” on May 28th. My PhD thesis can be found [here]. A recording of my defence can be found [here]. This presentation is aimed at a broad audience and should be followable without background knowledge.

item.title: Other projects
item.description: Engineering and science communications have always been passions of mine. However, I’m always looking forward to broaden my horizon with new and challenging projects. A non-exhaustive (and quite random) list of projects and experiences in which I took part can be found below. Exploitation of research: technology & knowledge transfer: 5 days training on research valorisation by KU Leuven Research & Development (LRD), including sessions on intellectual property law, industry collaboration and exploitation plans and with a hands-on project on validation of research results.

item.title: Science Communication
item.description: Wetenschapsbattle / Battle of the Scientists: Science communication challenge: present your research to children age 6-12. I was selected of one of the five finalists and presented my work to an audience of 3500 children. (in dutch) [link] Science figured out: How to keep a secret?: 3 minute video presentation on the need for post-quantum cryptography and side-channel attacks for a broad audience (in dutch) [link]

item.title: About me
item.description: Iâ€™m a post-doctoral researcher in the COSIC research group at KU Leuven, Belgium. I’m currently mostly involved in BELFORT, our hardware accelerator for Homomorphic Encryption BELFORT. My research interests include implementation and acceleration of fully homomorphic encryption; and development, security and side-channel secure implementation of post-quantum encryption. I was involved in the development of the encryption algorithm Saber, which is one of the candidates for standardization in the NIST post-quantum standardization process.
